Research

My Ph.D. research was mainly focused on investigating the fundamental limits of communication in networks through an information theoretic perspective (Project 2). After graduation, I leveraged the deep connection between information theory and large deviations theory as well as my training as a masters student in applied mathematics to study a range of research areas including privacy and security (Project 1), wireless communications (Project 3 and Project 4), and learning theory (Project 5). As a research faculty at the New York University, I was fortunate to be introduced to several new research areas  through my membership at NYU Wireless and also my close collaboration with the center for cybersecurity (CCS). 

 

In collaboration with CCS, we started a project on quantifying the users' privacy risks in social networks (Project 1). I was the Co-PI of the NSF grant #CCF-1815821 titled `An Information Theoretic Framework for Web Privacy'.  This research has also resulted in several recent publications.

In NYU Wireless, our frequent contacts with the center's affiliates including Samsung, InterDigital, Nokia, Qualcomm, and Ericsson, has enabled me to better understand the state of the art in communication systems and the relevant future areas of interest. My research in this area led to several recent papers on multi-user scheduling and energy efficient MIMO communication (Project 3 and Project 4).

Furthermore, in collaboration with my Ph.D. advisor, we have initiated research on application of some of our prior observations in multi-terminal communications  to the problem of feature selection and function approximation which is of significant interest in learning theory (Project 5).
